Rio: City of Nature

The city holds the world's largest urban forest: the sprawling Tijuca National Park, Established in 1961. The Tijuca Forest carpets 3,953 hectares of reclaimed land that was previously cleared for coal and coffee production. Tijuca is now home to a mosaic of trails, cascading waterfalls, wildlife, viewpoints and famous landmarks (most notably the art deco Christ the Redeemer statue).

Start scrolling for a tour with my favorite spots to experience the city's rich nature.

Pedra da Gávea

Pedra da Gávea is the highest rock directly by the sea in the world. It is located near Barra de Tijuca beach from where the trail starts. The summit is 2,762.47 feet (842 meters) high and offers a fantastic 360-degree view. From here, you see the famous Statue of Christ and the Sugarloaf Mountain as well as the long sandy beaches of the city. You also have a perfect view of the countless paragliders that take off from neighboring Pedra Bonita.

Açude do Camorim

The Açude do Camorim is located in Pedra Branca Park, very close to the Rio Centro. The trail is very easy, has some climbs, and has access to the Véu da Noiva Waterfall. Inside the forest, in a basin closed by the mountains, is the weir, with an area of 435 meters above sea level. The dam is not natural, but it was planned, forming one of the most beautiful corners of the Marvelous City.

Prainha

Prainha Beach is one of Rio's most eye-catching and popular beaches. It is a small surfers' beach surrounded by rocks and high cliffs that you definitely want to add to your Rio bucket list.

Prainha has 150 meters of sand and 700 meters long. It is surrounded and protected by hills and stones that have typical vegetation of native Atlantic Forest. This beach has a unique beauty. With clear sand, crystal clear water, in addition to a spring of freshwater and fantastic waves.

Pedra do Telégrafo
